title: How to Make a Cheese Mouse

steps.headline: Use cream cheese already shaped into little quarters or wedges.
steps.description: These are often of European origin and come in an array of tasty flavors, wrapped in foil. (For example, Laughing Cow Swiss cheese wedges.)

steps.headline: Remove the foil from the quarter.
Add ears.
steps.description: Cut small slivers of sausage (meat or vegetarian) to make the ears. Insert at the pointed tip end of the wedge, which is the face end of the mouse.

steps.headline: Add eyes.
steps.description: Add small black sesame seeds, pepitas, or flecks of olives for the eyes.

steps.headline: Add a nose.
steps.description: Cut a small piece of olive with the end of a straw and add the circle to the tip of the wedge.

steps.headline: Add the tail.
steps.description: For example, a piece of chive stem or a length of pretzel. If you have the ability to make long curls from vegetables, use carrot or celery curls for the tail.

steps.headline: Place the mouse on the cheeseboard.
Use soft cheese with an oval shape for this style.
steps.description: For example, a small mozzarella or bocconcini cheese shape.

steps.headline: Slice very think round slivers of radish.
steps.description: Insert these into the head end of the cheese, to form ears.

steps.headline: Add eyes.
steps.description: Use sultanas or raisins for eyes. Alternatively, cut small slivers of olives to serve as eyes. (An easy way to cut the olive is to pierce it with the end of a straw, to make a perfect circle.)

steps.headline: Add the nose.
steps.description: Use a sultana or a peppercorn for a nose.

steps.headline: Place a tail on the mouse.
steps.description: For example, a piece of chive stem or a length of pretzel. If you have the ability to make long curls from vegetables, use carrot or celery curls for the tail.

steps.headline: Add whiskers.
steps.description: This part is optional but if you'd like a few whiskers, cut some very fine slivers of celery and place them where whiskers would appear.

steps.headline: Place several of these mice on the cheeseboard or on a serving platter in a circle, placed centrally on the cheeseboard or next to it.
steps.description: They look more effective as a group. They're now ready to serve.

steps.headline: Use a Camembert, Brie, or similar style of cheese of round shape with a thick rind.
Cut even triangles from the cheese round.
Add ears.
steps.description: Cut small rounds of radish, carrot, zucchini or similar vegetables with round shapes. Insert two ears per wedge, adding the ears about a quarter of the way from the large end of the triangle (well away from the tip).

steps.headline: Add a nose.
steps.description: Cut small triangle wedges from olives for the nose. Place on the very tip of each wedge.

steps.headline: Add the eyes.
steps.description: For the eyes, cut out slits of sundried tomatoes, roasted peppers, or similar. Place these a little below the ear area. Play around with the exact placement until the look seems most mouse like to you.

steps.headline: Place on the cheeseboard or a serving platter.
steps.description: It's now ready to serve. An alternative way of serving is to place the mice directly onto cheese crackers for ease of picking up and eating. This can dispense with handling difficulties!

text: Cream cheese wedge mouse Use cream cheese already shaped into little quarters or wedges. These are often of European origin and come in an array of tasty flavors, wrapped in foil. (For example, Laughing Cow Swiss cheese wedges.) Remove the foil from the quarter.  Add ears. Cut small slivers of sausage (meat or vegetarian) to make the ears. Insert at the pointed tip end of the wedge, which is the face end of the mouse. Add eyes. Add small black sesame seeds, pepitas, or flecks of olives for the eyes. Add a nose. Cut a small piece of olive with the end of a straw and add the circle to the tip of the wedge. Add the tail. For example, a piece of chive stem or a length of pretzel. If you have the ability to make long curls from vegetables, use carrot or celery curls for the tail. Place the mouse on the cheeseboard. It's now ready to serve. Bocconcini style mouse Use soft cheese with an oval shape for this style. For example, a small mozzarella or bocconcini cheese shape. Slice very think round slivers of radish. Insert these into the head end of the cheese, to form ears. Add eyes. Use sultanas or raisins for eyes. Alternatively, cut small slivers of olives to serve as eyes. (An easy way to cut the olive is to pierce it with the end of a straw, to make a perfect circle.) Add the nose. Use a sultana or a peppercorn for a nose. Place a tail on the mouse. For example, a piece of chive stem or a length of pretzel. If you have the ability to make long curls from vegetables, use carrot or celery curls for the tail. Add whiskers. This part is optional but if you'd like a few whiskers, cut some very fine slivers of celery and place them where whiskers would appear. Place several of these mice on the cheeseboard or on a serving platter in a circle, placed centrally on the cheeseboard or next to it. They look more effective as a group. They're now ready to serve. Camembert style mouse Use a Camembert, Brie, or similar style of cheese of round shape with a thick rind.  Cut even triangles from the cheese round.  Add ears. Cut small rounds of radish, carrot, zucchini or similar vegetables with round shapes. Insert two ears per wedge, adding the ears about a quarter of the way from the large end of the triangle (well away from the tip). Add a nose. Cut small triangle wedges from olives for the nose. Place on the very tip of each wedge. Add the eyes. For the eyes, cut out slits of sundried tomatoes, roasted peppers, or similar. Place these a little below the ear area. Play around with the exact placement until the look seems most mouse like to you. Place on the cheeseboard or a serving platter. It's now ready to serve. An alternative way of serving is to place the mice directly onto cheese crackers for ease of picking up and eating. This can dispense with handling difficulties!
